question: You are a code expert. Please use your professional knowledge to generate accurate and professional responses. Make sure the code you generate is executable and ready for demonstration. Based on the data in this table, please generate three 3D pie charts for me. The first one should show the age distribution, divided into categories of 20-25 years old, 26-30 years old, 31-35 years old, 36-40 years old, and over 40 years old, displaying the proportion of each category. The second one should show the gender distribution, divided into male and female, displaying the proportion of each category. The third one should show the education distribution, divided into bachelor's degree, master's degree, and doctorate, displaying the proportion of each category.

checklist.title: Is the age distribution 3D pie chart implemented correctly?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the code accurately groups and displays the age data in a 3D pie chart with the specified categories (20-25, 26-30, 31-35, 36-40, and over 40). Check if proportions are calculated correctly and if the visualization reflects accurate percentages. Score 0 if the chart is missing, 5 if the basic implementation has errors in grouping or calculation, and 10 if the age distribution chart is fully implemented with proper labels and accurate proportions.

checklist.title: Is the gender distribution 3D pie chart implemented correctly?
checklist.description: Assess whether the code properly creates a 3D pie chart showing gender distribution (male and female). Verify that the data proportions are calculated accurately and the visualization clearly represents the gender ratio. Score 0 if the chart is missing, 5 if the basic implementation has calculation or display issues, and 10 if the gender distribution chart is completely implemented with proper labels and accurate percentages.

checklist.title: Is the education distribution 3D pie chart implemented correctly?
checklist.description: Review whether the code successfully implements a 3D pie chart showing education distribution (bachelor's, master's, doctorate). Confirm that the proportions reflect the actual data distribution and segments are properly labeled. Score 0 if the chart is missing, 5 if the implementation has data calculation or presentation flaws, and 10 if the education distribution chart is fully functional with accurate proportions and clear labeling.

checklist.title: Are the 3D visual effects properly implemented?
checklist.description: Evaluate the three-dimensional quality of the pie charts. Check for proper depth, perspective, lighting effects, and shadows that enhance the 3D appearance. Score 0 if charts are essentially 2D, 5 if 3D effects are basic (just extrusion without proper lighting/shadows), and 10 if charts feature professional 3D elements including proper depth perception, lighting, angle, and interactive viewing capabilities.

checklist.title: Is the code robust?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the code can handle common abnormal situations (such as missing data, incomplete data, negative values, extremely small percentage values, etc.) and provide friendly error prompts or recovery mechanisms. Code with strong robustness should be able to effectively handle these edge cases, giving 10 points. If the robustness is average, give 5 points, and if no exceptions are handled, give 0 points.

checklist.title: Are there any innovative features that are eye-catching?
checklist.description: Check whether the code includes surprise features that enhance the experience (e.g., 1. Interactive tooltips with detailed statistics 2. Animation transitions between chart views 3. Custom color palettes with thematic consistency 4. Drill-down capabilities to explore subcategories). Add 3 points for each practical innovative feature implemented (maximum 10 points).

checklist.title: Are there any redundant features?
checklist.description: Strictly check three types of redundancy: 1. Redundant implementation of similar visualization functions (e.g., multiple charting libraries used for the same purpose) 2. Function modules unrelated to the requested charts (e.g., extraneous analytics) 3. Fancy effects that affect performance (e.g., excessive animations that slow rendering). Deduct 3 points for each redundancy found, and directly deduct 10 points if the core functions are interfered with by redundant code.

checklist.title: Does the code have engineering quality?
checklist.description: Review modular design (such as separating data processing/visualization logic/user interface layers), reusability of chart creation functions, and code organization. Deduct 5 points if global state pollution is found or design patterns are not used; deduct 5 points if the code duplication rate is too high (over 30%); deduct 5 points if the initialization process is not properly structured. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Does the interface vision meet professional design standards?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the overall design follows modern data visualization principles: 1) Harmonious color matching (no more than 3 primary colors per chart) 2) Proper layout spacing (charts properly sized and positioned) 3) Professional typography (readable labels with proper contrast). Deduct 3 points for each visually cramped element, 5 points for clashing colors that hamper readability, and 5 points for poorly positioned or sized labels/legends. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is the dynamic interaction smooth and seamless?
checklist.description: Judge whether the interaction features conform to modern visualization standards: 1) Responsive hover effects with tooltips â‰¤ 100ms delay 2) Smooth rotation/perspective changes for 3D visualization 3) Clear visual cues for interactive elements. Deduct 5 points for each interaction without feedback, 3 points for jerky animations or transitions, and 5 points for inaccessible or unintuitive interaction controls. The full score is 10 points.
